title: CTRL0000082308 - Transcribed Interview of Madison Fox Porter, (May 5, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 2:00 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
We can go on the record.
This is a transcribed interview conducted by the Select Committee to Investigate the
January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
Ms. Porter, could you please state your full name and spell it for the record.
It's Madison Fox Porter, and that's M-a-d-i-s-o-n, middle
This will be a staff-led interview.
select committee may join if they so choose and ask questions, but in the main, it will be
me asking questions and my colleague who's with me in the room,
I know that you have your attorney with you today, so I would ask him to please
I'm a senior investigative counsel, a n d - i s an
introduce himself and spell his last name for the record.
So before we begin, Ms. Porter, what I'll do is just go over a few ground rules,
standard for anybody who meets with us.
platform, that we have official reporters with us who are transcribing what you're saying
until we're done asking it, and we'll wait to ask you the next question until you're done
The official reporters can only record verbal answers, so if you shake
The first is to note, as you see on the Webex
So if you could, for the record, if you could please wait to answer our question
or nod your head, excuse us in advance, we'll have to ask you to say yes or no.
you spell something that we don't know the spelling of, we'll just ask you to please spell
that so everyone knows for the record what it is you're referring to.
We ask that you provide complete answers, based on the best of
And if a question we ask is not clear, just let us know, and we'll do our best to rephrase it
If you need any break at any point, whether for comfort or just to
If you don't remember something or you're not clear on it, just say so.
talk to Mr. Passantino, we're happy to accommodate that.
I've told Mr. Passantino before today that I expect us to be efficient with your
us, so I don't expect it to go more than, say, 2 hours at the most.
I know you're busy and have a family to get to and we appreciate you being with
But, again, if you need a break at any time, just let us know and we'll
Now, throughout the interview, as we talked about before we went
on the record, we referred to the fact that we'll be showing you exhibits.
is we'll flash those up on the screen so that you can see them.
We provided them in advance yesterday so that you and Mr. Passantino could see
them and review them, but you take as much time as you need today if you need it to
refamiliarize yourself with the documents before you answer questions, okay?
And if you need us to zoom in, please let us know and we'll do that.
We'll navigate the best we can in this format.
I'll say up front, there's one exhibit we didn't send yesterday.
of President Trump's tweets and specifically from January 6th.
you need time to look at them with your attorney or think about them, it was just
something I forgot to send yesterday, so you do what you need when we get to that
I'll show them to you at some point during the interview toward the end, but if
But otherwise, just want to remind you, as we do all witnesses
before we get started, that it's unlawful to deliberately provide false information to
Congress and that to do so could result in criminal penalties.
So, with that, I just want to note for the record that you're appearing today
So I reached out to you by text, and then you arranged to get counsel,
Mr. Passantino, and so there was no need for us to have to subpoena you.
Now, I did send to Mr. Passantino a set of document requests to see if you
had anything that was responsive, and if we show that now, it's exhibit 1.
And let us know if you can see the exhibit on your screen.
So this is the email I sent with the document requests on April
Please understand we don't want to hear anything about discussions
That's between the two of you.
But I'll just ask, did you look to see within the documents you have in your
possession whether you had anything responsive to the requests we had?
And did you have anything that was responsive?
As we understand it through your counsel, that's because anything
responsive you would have had would have been communicated over your White House
devices at the time, and you no longer have access to those.
So moving beyond that then, we can take down that exhibit.
Could you just give us some background, Ms. Porter, on your highest level of
education and your career path leading up to your working at the White House?
I graduated from Texas A&M University with a bachelor's degree, and
worked on the Hill for 4 years on the House side, and then moved to the White House in
When you joined the White House, in what role did you join at that time?
At that time, I joined as senior writer in the Office of Presidential
What was the last title you held before the end of President Trump's
The last title that I held was Associate Staff Secretary and Special Assistant to
How long had you held that title and role for before you left at the end
That specific title, I'm not sure.
As we understand it, a gentleman by the name of Derek Lyons was serving as
How long had you been in the Staff Secretary's
the staff secretary for a period of time overlapping with your tenure in the office.
And that he left the office on December 19th of 2020.
So at the time he left, did that cause any change in your title or role and
It may have been around the same time.
Maybe a simpler way to ask it, was there someone who, in effect, stood
in -- took Mr. Lyons place at least officially when he left and, if so, was it you or someone
No, there was no one who officially took his position.
So just maintain the status quo through the end of the administration about
Could you give us just an overview of what your responsibility was in that
role within the Staff Secretary's Office?
And if it's different in the time period we're
interested in, November of 2020 to January of 2021, let us know, but otherwise, you can
just describe during your 2 years what that role required of you?
that those documents were in good shape, documents including executive orders,
not in charge of creating content, just more so the facilitating of these documents.
So in the Office of the Staff Secretary, I would explain it as sort of like
We were in charge of facilitating documents.
And then, we would deliver a final product.
When it comes to speeches in particular, could you just give us a sense of
what the role was of the Staff Secretary's Office, speeches that the President would
We would receive a draft from the speech writing team.
route it out to the appropriate principals.
compile that, send that back to the speechwriters.
until the speechwriters felt it was in a good position to be delivered to the President.
And then, we would take all of the edits,
Just so we put some names and faces with the roles and the time we're
interested in, again, we're going to focus on November of 2020 to January of 2021, and if
you're ever -- if I'm ever not clear about that, just let me know, but that's what we're
We understand that Vince Haley and Ross Worthington were basically the heads
of the speechwriting team during that time.
And they reported up to Stephen Miller, who ultimately was responsible for
And so, as in the standard process for getting a speech to the President, did
you know or did you have visibility into the back-and-forth between Ross and Vince on
the one hand, and Stephen Miller before it would come to you for the Staff Secretary
In other words, would they hash out and get the draft in shape before -We lost her.
So just for the record, it's 2:10 and Ms. Porter dropped off.
You know what, I was running on, so this makes it
I'm just going to go back to understand the process, and maybe the easiest
way is for you to tell me if it's right or wrong.
We understand that Mr. Worthington and Mr. Haley would do a first draft, get it
to Mr. Miller, and they would hash out the first draft together before it would then go to
you and the Staff Secretary's Office to go out to the different components of the White
House for another look before it went to the President.
Does that sound right to you?
And while I understand that every speech is unique, the process once you
got involved with the Staff Secretary's Office, was that iterative, or it was just a one-time
you send it out, people give their responses, the speechwriting team incorporate it and
then it goes to the President, or were there multiple levels of review?
There were multiple levels of review.
Now, as a general matter, would you and the Staff Secretary's Office have
any visibility into the assignment of speeches on the front end before you would receive
Would you know what was being asked of the team and when they were
I'm not sure I understand what you mean by that question.
So just take as just a -- let's just take a hypothetical speech.
President has an event coming up in 2 weeks, and Mr. Worthington and Mr. Haley need
Would you know in advance that they were working on it and that you needed to
get it by a certain time for it to be reviewed and finalized to go to the President, or you
would just receive it when you received it and take it from there?
mean, yeah, that was about it.
We'll go back on the record at 2:14.
And in the typical process, would the President provide any input?
I think for the record, it looks like Ms. Porter's connection froze up
Usually would receive it when we received it and take it from there.
But, Ms. Porter, the question I was asking before we had that interruption
was just in the typical course, would President Trump provide input on a speech prior to
receiving the draft after the Staff Secretary review?
Is your question who he would be providing that information to or --
Just to the best of your knowledge, did you understand the President, would
he provide input on a speech as a general matter before he received the draft after the
When he would provide input after receiving the draft that came
out of the Staff Secretary review process, would you see that?
in other words, would it come to your office to deliver to the speechwriters, or would it
And when it did come to you the sometimes, would it be in hardcopy
Would it be in a red line, in an electronic document?
Sometimes it would be a redline copy document.
And to that point, where was your office located, at least in the 3 months
we're looking at, within the West Wing?
So when you walk into the West Wing and you see the reception
desk where the Secret Service agent sits, you make a left.
So on the same floor as the Oval Office?
So you'd have to walk up or down to get to the Oval?
It's the last left on your left across from the restroom, and then I -- yeah, I sat
You go all the way down the
Just for the record, it's 2:16 and Ms. Porter's system froze
Let me go back on the record at 2:35.
appears, the technical issues and we'll get back to the interview.
Ms. Porter, when we stopped talking before the technical issues came up,
we were just going over the standard process for speechwriting, and thank you for giving
us a sense of generally how it worked.
And I just want to turn to the particular now.
And I'm going to show you three
record because we need -- at 2:36 because we need to get the ability to share.
We are back on the record.
The issue, however, now is that we're going to go off the
Ms. Porter, what I'm showing you is exhibit 2, which is a photograph taken
by the White House photographer the evening of January 5th of 2021 in the Oval Office.
Do you see the photograph on the screen?
And just to orient for the record, on the right of the picture, the furthest to
And we understand that you are the person in the picture
standing next to him, what would be on his right.
And next to you to your right in the photograph would be Doug Sellers?
Does Mr. Sellers -- was he also in the Office of Staff Secretary at
And, again, I'll show you just a few more before we get to the particulars,
but if we look at exhibit 3, these are tweets that President Trump issued from his Twitter
account on the evening of January 5th, three in particular that we've highlighted:
first at 5:05 p.m., the next at 5:12 p.m., and then the last at 5:25 p.m.
So I won't read them, but do you see those highlighted there?
And then we'll look at exhibit 4, which is an email chain within the White
House email system from January 5th of 2021.
What I want to do is direct your
attention to the first two emails in the chain, which are going to be on page 2 of exhibit 4.
What starts the chain is an email from Austin Ferrer at 5:11 p.m. on January
5th, so in between the two tweets that the President issued.
And it's to Vince Haley and Ross Worthington, the speechwriters we
discussed earlier, copying Molly Michael and the Staff Secretary email address.
And the subject line is the 11 a.m. speech?
Now, the Staff Secretary email address doesn't name a particular person, but
was that a distribution list to your office?
So you would have received this email then?
And to that point, if we go up to the next email in the chain, we need go to
the bottom of page 1 to show you the date and time, but on January 5th at 5:28 p.m., it
lists you as having replied to the chain.
And if you go down to the body of it, it says:
feedback from POTUS re: the remarks.
Are you the Madison Porter who sent that email?
And the timing, as you see, 5:28 p.m. is approximately 3 minutes after
President Trump sent the last of the three tweets that I showed you in exhibit 3, okay?
And then to continue on, just so you can see, the response and
then continuing on in this chain is that Mr. Haley, Vince Haley, if we go down, at 6:02 p.m.
We anticipate delivery by 8 p.m. at the
You're on that chain, so you received it.
If we go up then to the next email in the chain, you know, Mr. Ferrer
And then next up, Mr. Ferrer checks in again at 7:40 p.m., literally saying:
Any chance we can get it before 8?"
And then if you continue up, I just need to explain to you a timing convention.
You'll see that Ross Worthington responds.
but the way the White House system, when it -- when this email is produced to us, that's
in UTC, or Greenwich Mean Time, which means it was 5 hours in advance of Eastern Time.
It's listed here as January 6th at 12:46 a.m.,
So if you subtract 5 hours, what that means is it was sent at 7:46 p.m. on January
5th, in other words, a few minutes after Mr. Ferrer checked in to see if he could get it
And, again, if you see there, the Staff Secretary is on the email
distribution list, and so you would have received this as well, right?
We've included the actual attachment that Mr. Worthington sent,
the speech that he sends at that time.
we'll go down just so you can see the start.
It's still on this exhibit, starting at page 3.
And again, just setting the stage, but if we go to exhibit 5, I'm going
to show you an email that you were not on, but that Mr. Worthington sent earlier on
January 5th at 3:30 p.m. to Stephen Miller and Vince Haley, with an earlier draft of the
And if you continue on to page 2, you'll see that the body of the speech is
And so, consistent with what you described earlier about what your role in the
review process would be in the Staff Secretary Office, what you see here is Ross and Vince
and Stephen discussing the first draft before it then comes to your office and others, with
the second draft at roughly 7:46 p.m. the night of January 5th.
And then last, just for context again, we ran a red line in exhibit 6
between the first draft that you weren't copied on and the second draft that you were
And the reason for that is because we'll direct your attention to certain language
and see if it's relevant to what we'll ask you about when you --
For clarification purposes, this is your redline?
Not the Staff Sec red line?
We understand there were certainly those that would be
passed around, but we took these and compared the two versions that we had, the first
and the second, and made a redline.
So, with all of that context now that you've seen it, what I'll do is go back to
exhibit 2, the photo in the Oval Office, and ask do you recall being at that, what I'll call a
gathering in the Oval Office the night of January 5th with the President?
And how did you come to be there for that gathering?
come in and why were you there?
I was there -- Douglas and I were both there to get, I want to say it was
And how would we know that's what we're looking at in the photo?
As you look at the photo, can you actually see on the Resolute Desk any of
We -- they typically came to us in these hard blue folder-type things.
right, closest to me you see the stack.
When you came in to have the President sign those bills, who else, if anyone, was
in the Oval Office with him at that time, do you remember?
As we look at this photo at this time, what we see, as we understand it, is
Kayleigh McEnany and many of the people on her team in the Communications Office.
Does that look right to you?
And then sitting on the couch -- and you can't see his face, his back is to the
Were all of these people, to your knowledge, in there when you first came in
with Mr. Sellers to have the bills signed, or did they come in after?
If you look at the middle of the picture, you can see what we understand to
be an open door in the Oval Office leading out to, I think the walkway towards the
When you came into the Oval Office that night with Mr. Sellers, was that
door already open, or was it opened while you were in there?
Do you remember it being -- what the temperature was like that night?
It was early January, and reporting and also accounts by other people in the
room with you said that it was quite cold and that people commented on being -- for
instance, some people were in short sleeves.
Do you remember that at all?
And at least yourself, you're standing a little ways away from the door in
I showed you in exhibit 3 tweets that went out from the President's Twitter
account between 5:05 p.m. and 5:25 p.m., three of them.
Do you recall tweets being discussed, or draft tweets being discussed while you
were in the Oval Office at that time?
So why -- understanding that then, what -- as best you can
remember, what was discussed, what was the nature of your conversation in the Oval
Office while you were there that night?
and carrying those up the stairs, I vividly remember that.
Like I said, I know we were there to get
That vividly sticks out in my mind, because there were 30-something
I remember vaguely discussions about tweets, or tweets being sent out.
remember what the content of those tweets were.
I showed them to you, though, and if you look -- we'll go back to exhibit 3
And we'll start with the first one at 5:05 p.m., and I'll read it:
is being inundated with people who don't want to see an election victory stolen by
We hear you and love you from the Oval Office.
But that's referring to hearing someone from the Oval Office and that
Washington is inundated with people who don't want to see the election victory stolen.
Do you recall any discussion of crowd noise and music while you were in the Oval
So what do you remember hearing outside and what do you remember
I remember the -- being able to hear music.
And I'm not trying to be vague.
I mean, right outside the door of
the Oval Office or it's coming from somewhere in the vicinity in the city downtown?
What do you mean, you heard music?
I would say the latter is correct.
I don't know where it was
specifically coming from, but you could hear people celebrating and you could hear
So not on the White House grounds, but somewhere close enough you could
No, not on the White House grounds.
Do you know -- does that refresh your recollection about why the door was
Did the President refer to the fact that he was listening to the people
I mean, what the tweet -- that's what was implied by the tweet.
I'll just say, if you're on mute, that there was kind of a series
of echoes that made it almost inaudible.
client, but I don't know if there's another way to communicate.
communicate with her, it might be easier to take a break, but up to you.
Well, you let me know if you need to continue,
but it sounds like, Ms. Porter, if you're comfortable continuing.
It was only about rephrasing the question.
I don't mean to get in between you and your
Again, just asking -- I want to ask this:
Was it typical with -- if there
was -- in early January for the President to keep the door open to the outside in the Oval
In my experience, no, but I also wasn't in there all the time, so I don't -- I
don't know what his preferences were with regard to the door.
But, in terms of your experience when you were in there, it was not typical
for him to have the door open in the winter like that?
What did the President say about the people who were there if he -- did he
comment on who they were and his views on the music?
I mean, what was he saying
I mean, I --1 don't recall his specific conversation.
tweet, but I don't remember what he spoke about.
Was he discussing it with people in the room, with you all, commenting to
you all, at least do you remember that?
It's been reported by witnesses that we've talked with who were in the room
with you, but then also in the book, Peril, by Bob Woodward and Robert Acosta that the
President during the meeting with you all said something to the effect of isn't that great
about the crowd and the music, tomorrow is going to be a big day, and Judd Deere
responding something to the effect of, you know, they are excited to hear from you, Mr.
Is that consistent, at least generally, with the tenor of the conversation?
It's also been reported in Peril that another staffer in the room said
something to the effect of that they hoped Wednesday, that is, January 6th, would be
peaceful, and other people said that they agreed, and that the President responded, Yes,
but there's a lot of anger out there right now.
Do you recall anything to that effect?
What, if anything else, do you remember, as best you can, the President
I mean, this has been over a year ago.
Again, I can infer from the tweets.
I don't -- I don't remember specifics.
I don't recall him saying anything about the bills we
I just -- I was up there to get those signed.
Do you recall him saying anything to the
effect -- the President, that is -- of how we, and referring to the people in the room, can
get Republicans, and even RINOs, in his term, to do the right thing on January 6th?
you remember that being a topic of conversation?
No, it wasn't, or you don't remember if it was?
And do you recall the President saying that the Republicans in Congress and
the RINOs, that is, Republican in name only, in particular, needed to have courage, as did
the Vice President, for what they were about to do on January 6th?
I don't remember the specific conversation.
Well, if we look at the second tweet in exhibit 3, do you see 5:12 p.m. on
ineffective RINO section of the Republican Party are looking at the thousands of people
"I hope the Democrats and, even more importantly, the weak and
They won't stand for a landslide election victory to be stolen."
And then he tweets that to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Senator
John Cornyn and Senator John Thune.
Does that refresh your recollection about whether the President was talking
I mean, again, I can infer from the tweet he must have been, but I don't -- I
I cannot recall the specifics of his conversation.
Do you recall the President speaking towards Dan Scavino, again, while all of
you were there, and talking about what to draft and to send out these tweets about what
he was hearing from the people outside?
I mean, again, there's the photo that shows Dan on his phone.
But you said earlier you did at least recall that there was some discussion of
tweets while you were in the room?
And to the question I asked earlier about whether the President referred to
I don't remember the specifics of the tweet, but yes.
a lot of anger being out there in the crowd, and people saying they hoped it would be
peaceful on Wednesday the 6th, you see the last tweet at 5:25 p.m. from the President is:
And then he tweets out various law enforcement-related
Again, does that refresh your recollection about whether there was
any discussion while you were there about whether it would be peaceful or not on
It does not refresh my memory.
Did you have -- were you aware that the President, at that time, that he
would be speaking the next day at the rally on the Ellipse?
I'd have to look at the timestamps of when I received the
Again, and I referred to earlier about how Judd Deere is reported to have
said that the people were excited to hear the President speak the next day.
So you don't recall that being discussed, the fact that the President would be
Again, specifics, I don't remember specifics from the conversation.
But then certainly, it would probably help to look at exhibit 4, which we
showed you earlier, the email chain about the draft speech for the next day.
If we bring you to page 2, as I showed you, Austin Ferrer reached out to the
speechwriters, Vince and Ross, at 5:11 p.m. --
-- asking for the speech tomorrow a.m., which you were on.
Was Mr. Ferrer in that meeting in the Oval Office, that you recall?
I didn't know you were still going.
How about Nick Luna, do you remember him coming into the Oval
At 5:28 p.m. then, when you respond back, Ross and Vince, we got some
feedback from POTUS regarding the remarks, Will give you a call, please, what prompted
that email and how did you get that feedback from the President?
Well, I assume that is what he -- he spoke about it in that -- in that
Again, I'm not asking you to assume.
you recall about why you reached out to Ross and Vince to tell them you had feedback?
I -- I mean, I've got the email.
what he said in the meeting, but there would obviously be a reason as to why I sent the
And as you see from the chain here, the President had not yet received the
And you certainly hadn't received the draft yet, that was the whole point of
And certainly, given your role, the President would know that you would be
in touch with the speechwriters about getting a draft in shape, right?
And so, you're saying you don't remember what he told you, but you know
enough, looking at this, that you received directly from the President whatever it is his
remarks were that he -- the feedback he wanted you to give to the speechwriters?
And you said "we" got some feedback, that is, in the collective,
When you said "we," who were you referring to?
I mean, I think I used "we" a lot in place of Staff Sec, so I'm
Do you recall who between the two of Ross and Vince, or maybe it was both,
So if you look at exhibit 6, the red line that we created between the first draft
and the second draft of this speech, and you see that what's stricken out in red is what's
taken out from the first draft.
And what's in blue underlined and not stricken through is words that are
added in the second draft, okay?
And we're looking at the first page, and you see that the introduction to the
first draft is stricken out and a new paragraph is added in.
I'm going to read that first paragraph, and then we'll talk about it.
paragraph in the second draft says:
devoted American patriots who are committed to the honesty of our elections and the
victory stolen by emboldened radical left Democrats.
"I am honored to stand before tens of thousands of
All of us here today do not want to see our election
Our country has had enough, we
Together, we will Stop the Steal."
Many of those words and certainly the tenor mirror what was in the President's
tweets that were sent a few minutes before you reached out.
Do you recall then, now having heard that and seen that, that the feedback
the President gave you had to do with the tweets he was sending out about the crowd?
Do you recall having to take notes, Ms. Porter, about the President's
feedback, or was it enough that you could just -- that you had it in your mind and
No, I think if I would have taken notes I probably would have put it in an
And so, to that point, if you see further in the draft where you see changes,
Do you mind, can I grab my glasses really quickly?
Let us know when you're ready.
Ms. Porter, we see you're back.
And we'll zoom out a bit so that you can see.
No, I'm sorry, zoom out so it's less big.
If we go down a bit -- and I'm just showing you that the types of changes -- again,
you had this yesterday, but I just want to show and continue on.
There's a portion of the speech, as you see, that has to do with purported facts
about the votes in the various States and numbers of ballots and those sorts of things.
Are you seeing that on page 3?
I'm just going to ask a simple point, that if there were changes with numbers
and about the various different States, I imagine that would have been the thing you
would have needed to take notes on to give detailed feedback like that, right?
And so, once Mr. Worthington sent the draft to you and others at
7:46 p.m., as we saw in the email chain, do you recall that this speech went through the,
what I'll call the standard Staff Secretary review process?
Is there anything about what happened with the speech at that point that
stands out in your mind as out of the ordinary?
The nature of the speech was at the -- you know, was at the Ellipse the next
And we've heard from other people involved in the speechwriting process that you
can basically break a speech down.
Do those categorizations seem -- make sense to you?
It's either an official speech or a political speech.
And so on the one hand, with an official speech, the entire speechwriting
process could be handled on White House computers and equipment; but if it was
political, you'd have to be mindful of the Hatch Act, at least to some extent, and
potentially use your personal account, is that right, for drafting?
But when it came into the Staff Secretary review process, whether official or
political, it would all be in the White House system, because that was the requirement to
then have it go to the components to review.
In other words, from your perspective in your office, it didn't matter
whether it was an official or a political speech, your review process was the same?
We understand that there might have been feedback from Eric
Herschmann -- do you know who Mr. Herschmann is?
-- regarding the purported facts about the ballots in the various States and
raising the issue whether people had fact-checked everything in there and checked the
Do you recall that sort of discussion about this speech in particular?
And what vaguely do you remember about that?
So -- and I believe -- I'm sure you have the emails.
that I routed this speech, sent it through the Staff Sec process.
making comments, but I don't -- I don't believe that I am the one who sent this out, so it's
harder for me to recall specifically.
I believe I was just on
So I have some recollection of individuals, you know,
But in particular, when it comes to Mr. Herschmann and commenting about
making sure that all the facts in this speech were correct and properly sourced, do you
remember that specifically in the context of this speech?
